metadata.sermon_title: God Made Jesus to Be Sin
metadata.sermon_start_end: t the very end of this service we will be reading Psalm 22 to.gether. It begins with these words, "My God, my God, why hast thou forsaken me?" Those of you who stay to the end of these three hours will see that this Psalm written hundreds of years [...] Our Lord Jesus Christ loved us with such an unrivalled love that he determined to step into our place and take our unbearable burden upon himself as though it had been his own. He bowed his head and became subject to the dark Powers, and for that one soul-destroying moment.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon lacks a single specific pericope. It drifts between Psalm 22, 2 Corinthians 5:21, Psalm 88, and Psalm 38. By treating the Bible as a collection of proof-texts for the 'Cry of Dereliction', it fails to find what is unique to ONE passage. It presents 'general truths' about the atonement rather than the specific voice of a single text.
quotes: Psalm 22 was one of the most amazing of all the texts.
In the second letter of Paul to the Corinthians, there is a sentence of great importance.
There is a portion of another Psalm that will help us here: (Psalm 38:3-4)
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Select either the Psalm or the Pauline verse as the sole foundation. Stop using other texts as 'keys' and instead exhaust the specific vocabulary and context of one passage.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: There is a basic awareness of the Psalms as a Jewish prayer book and the Greek of Mark, but the exegesis is quickly swallowed by dogmatic synthesis. The 'original meaning' for the first readers of the Psalms is largely ignored in favor of a Christological reading that assumes the meaning is already known.
quotes: Mark's Greek indicates that he cried out on the Cross with a desperate kind of scream.
The voice of the speaker in that Psalm as it was originally written and sung was the voice of a human being.
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Spend more time on the historical-grammatical reality of the chosen text before jumping to the 'discovery' of the early church.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is remarkably vague. It deals with 'human nature' and 'people who are angry', but lacks the concrete, cultural, or political specificity Dekker demands. It remains in the realm of 'spiritual life' without touching the zeitgeist or the specific world of the hearer.
quotes: Human nature being what it is, we would have expected...
I often recommend to people who are so angry at God that they cannot pray.
No matter how dark and terrible your thoughts may be...
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Connect the 'gravity of sin' to specific contemporary manifestations of 'misery' in the congregation's social or personal reality.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon is more of a thematic meditation than an interwoven exposition. It moves from a historical 'imagination' of the disciples to a dogmatic explanation. The hearer is an observer of the disciples' discovery rather than being 'expounded' by the text themselves.
quotes: Imagine yourself as one of the disciples trying to make sense...
Now perhaps we can see. The voice of the speaker... was my voice, your voice.
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Use the text to directly address the hearer's current situation rather than asking them to 'imagine' being a first-century disciple.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: This is the strongest point. The sermon takes 'misery' (abandonment, sin, anger) seriously and links it to 'redemption' (Christ taking the burden). It avoids a 'soft' misery. However, 'gratitude' is underdeveloped, as the sermon ends abruptly at the moment of the cross.
quotes: The price paid by the Lord is commensurate with the depth of human wickedness.
He took into himself the full weight of God's condemnation and judgment.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Develop the 'gratitude' aspect more clearly as the necessary response to such a high-priced redemption.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The 'seriousness of being lost' is present in the description of Christ's dereliction, but it is not presented as a choice or destination for the hearer. The 'two ways' are implied dogmatically but not homiletically urged upon the listener.
quotes: He took it so that it would be removed from us.
He bowed his head and became subject to the dark Powers.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Address the possibility of 'being lost in time' if one does not answer the calling presented by this grace.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: The sermon is highly Christocentric. Christ is clearly the telos. The doctrine of the two natures is present ('divine Son of God' / 'Man for Others'). It successfully points to salvation outside the self.
quotes: Christ as the goal of the sermon, man is ultimately detached from himself and pointed to salvation outside himself.
God made him to be sin who knew no sin, so that in him we might become the righteousness of God.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Ensure Christ is not just a 'solution' to a problem, but the specific Lord of the specific text handled.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 1350 words, the sermon likely lasts 13-14 minutes. According to Dekker, this is insufficient for the 'breadth' required for true depth. It feels like a 'meditation' (as the title suggests) rather than a full sermon.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the exposition and concrete application to reach at least 20 minutes (approx. 2000 words).

overall_assessment.summary: The text falls short of Dekker's definition of a sermon primarily due to its lack of a specific biblical anchor and its insufficient length. It functions as a thematic meditation on the Atonement rather than an exposition of a specific pericope. While it handles the 'misery' and 'Christocentric' aspects with theological weight, it fails to provide concrete, contemporary application and ignores the 'two ways' as a homiletical necessity.
strengths: Theological seriousness regarding the weight of sin and the reality of God-forsakenness.
Strong Christological focus that avoids moralism by emphasizing grace outside the self.
weaknesses: Homiletical fragmentation: jumping between multiple texts prevents the 'specific word' from emerging.
Lack of concrete application: the 'zeitgeist' is absent; the application remains in general spiritualities.
Insufficient length: the 13-minute duration precludes the necessary 'breadth' for depth.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is not a sermon in the strict sense of Dekker's theses; it is a theological meditation. It lacks the formal requirement of being an 'exposition and application of a specific Bible passage' and fails the 20-minute threshold for substantive preaching.
